A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node located in the retropharyngeal space behind the upper part of the pharynx.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located in the retropharyngeal space behind the upper part of the pharynx.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level III

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level III
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level III: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid or sensory branches of the cervical plexus. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level III
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level III: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid or sensory branches of the cervical plexus. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level IV

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level IV
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level IV: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid or sensory branches of the cervical plexus. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level IV
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level IV: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid or sensory branches of the cervical plexus. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IA: Superior: symphysis of the mandible; inferior: body of the hyoid; anterior (medial): anterior belly of the contralateral digastric muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior belly of the ipsilateral digastric muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IA
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IA: Superior: symphysis of the mandible; inferior: body of the hyoid; anterior (medial): anterior belly of the contralateral digastric muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior belly of the ipsilateral digastric muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IB

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IB
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IB: Superior: body of the mandible; inferior: posterior belly of the digastric muscle; anterior (medial): anterior belly of the digastric muscle; posterior (lateral): stylohyoid muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IB
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IB: Superior: body of the mandible; inferior: posterior belly of the digastric muscle; anterior (medial): anterior belly of the digastric muscle; posterior (lateral): stylohyoid muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IIA: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): stylohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIA
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IIA: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): stylohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIB

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIB
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IIB: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel IIB
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel IIB: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel VA: Superior: apex of the convergence of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle or sensory branches of the cervical plexus; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VA
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel VA: Superior: apex of the convergence of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle or sensory branches of the cervical plexus; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VB

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VB
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel VB: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Sublevel VB
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for sublevel VB: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VI

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VI
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level VI: Superior: hyoid bone; inferior: suprasternal notch; anterior (medial): common carotid artery; posterior (lateral): common carotid artery. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VI
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level VI: Superior: hyoid bone; inferior: suprasternal notch; anterior (medial): common carotid artery; posterior (lateral): common carotid artery. (AJCC 8th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VII

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VII
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level VII: Superior: suprasternal notch; inferior: innominate artery; anterior (medial): sternum; posterior (lateral): trachea, esophagus, and prevertebral fascia. (AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level VII
Concepts.definition: The following anatomical structures define the neck lymph node boundary for level VII: Superior: suprasternal notch; inferior: innominate artery; anterior (medial): sternum; posterior (lateral): trachea, esophagus, and prevertebral fascia. (AJCC 8th ed.)

The systematic withdrawal of fluids and discharges from a wound, sore or cavity.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
One, some, every, or all without specification.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level II
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Neck lymph node boundary level II contains the upper jugular nodal group. It is divided by the accessory nerve into sublevels IIA and IIB. The following anatomical structures define sublevel IIA: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): stylohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve. The following anatomical structures define sublevel IIB: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (partially adapted from AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level II
Concepts.definition: Neck lymph node boundary level II contains the upper jugular nodal group. It is divided by the accessory nerve into sublevels IIA and IIB. The following anatomical structures define sublevel IIA: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior border of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): stylohyoid muscle; posterior (lateral): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve. The following anatomical structures define sublevel IIB: Superior: skull base; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the inferior body of the hyoid bone; anterior (medial): vertical plane defined by the spinal accessory nerve; posterior (lateral): lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (partially adapted from AJCC 8th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level V
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Neck lymph node boundary level V contains the posterior triangle lymph node group. It includes the lymph nodes located along the lower half of the spinal accessory nerve and the transverse cervical artery. The supraclavicular nodes are also included in this group. It is divided into sublevels VA and VB. The following anatomical structures define sublevel VA: Superior: apex of the convergence of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle or sensory branches of the cervical plexus; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The following anatomical structures define sublevel VB: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (Partially adapted from AJCC 8th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Neck Lymph Node Boundary Level V
Concepts.definition: Neck lymph node boundary level V contains the posterior triangle lymph node group. It includes the lymph nodes located along the lower half of the spinal accessory nerve and the transverse cervical artery. The supraclavicular nodes are also included in this group. It is divided into sublevels VA and VB. The following anatomical structures define sublevel VA: Superior: apex of the convergence of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles; inferior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle or sensory branches of the cervical plexus; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The following anatomical structures define sublevel VB: Superior: horizontal plane defined by the lower border of the cricoid cartilage; inferior: clavicle; anterior (medial): posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle; posterior (lateral): anterior border of the trapezius muscle. (partially adapted from AJCC 8th ed.)
